title: Contributing to the OHDSI UK Website
text:
Thank you for your interest in contributing to the OHDSI UK website!
This site is built using Quarto and automatically deployed via GitHub Actions to GitHub Pages.


To contribute, youâ€™ll need the following installed locally:

Quarto CLI
R
Git or GitHub Desktop for a user-friendly interface

You can edit the code using any Integrated Development Environment that supports Quarto (e.g.Â RStudio, Positron, VS Code, or JupyterLab).
We recommend using RStudio as the repository includes a .Rproj file to simplify your workflow.





Before starting, we encourage you to open an issue to propose your idea or content. This helps avoid duplicated efforts and ensures your contribution aligns with the projectâ€™s direction.
While pull requests (PRs) are always welcome, we canâ€™t guarantee that all will be accepted â€” starting a discussion increases the chances your work will be merged.









After editing content or code, you can preview the website locally:
quarto preview
This will start a live preview server where you can see your changes.
Once youâ€™re satisfied commit them to Github.



Push your branch and open a Pull Request (PR).
ðŸ’¡ If the GitHub Actions check fails and youâ€™re unsure why, just leave a comment in the PR and a maintainer will assist.



Ask a maintainer to review your changes.




You do not need to manually render or deploy the website.
When changes are merged into the main branch:

A GitHub Action renders the site using Quarto.
The rendered output is automatically deployed to GitHub Pages.





Use Quarto Markdown syntax.
Keep filenames lowercase and use underscores (_) rather than spaces.
Use relative links to other pages (e.g., resources.qmd, not absolute URLs).
Place images in the images/ folder and optimize them for web use.




Please be respectful and professional in your interactions. See our CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md for details.
Thank you for contributing! ðŸŽ‰

The United Kingdom has more than 20 Data Partners in the EHDEN network and several EHDEN-certified SMEs. The UK scientific network is dynamic and research active, with numerous initiatives in the fields of health informatics, health data sciences, pharmacoepidemiology, and related areas.
Many UK partners have made substantial contributions to recent EHDEN- and OHDSI-sponsored research, and key national players like Health Data Research UK and the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) are increasingly interested in the use of OMOP for federated analytics nationally.



The aims of the UK national node include:

To adopt OHDSIâ€™s mission, vision, and values
To facilitate the coordination of national members at a national and international level with OHDSI and EHDEN partners
To promote the OHDSI mission in the UK in collaboration with relevant national stakeholders including academia, healthcare organizations, HTA agencies, regulators, patient organizations, policy makers, clinical guideline developers and pharmaceutical and life science industry
To initiate and/or collaborate in relevant national research collaborations and co-ordination with European and global OHDSI initiatives
To organize training programs in the field of Health Data Sciences and related areas
To engage with the European and global OHDSI leadership




Health Data Sciences Section, Botnar Research Centre, University of Oxford
